g.text: The forest plots of meta-analysis about CSER and RR: (
) Forest plot for CRS rate and CI in
solid and hematologic malignancies patients of each study and the overall; (
and CI in hematologic malignancies patients of each study and the overall; (
CI in solid and hematologic malignancies patients of each study and the overall.
2.6. Meta-Analysis of RR of CAR T Therapy in Patients with Solid and Hematologic Malignancies
achieved overall response after treatment, were eligible for the RR evaluation of CAR T therapy in
patients with solid and hematologic malignancies. The overall pooled RR and 95% CI from the
individual studies were 29% (95% CI: 21–38%) (Figure 4c), with a significant heterogeneity (I
< 0.01). The random-effect model was used to calculate them. The subgroup analysis of solid and
hematologic malignancies showed that the RR of patients with hematologic malignancies (29%, 95%
was similar to patients with solid malignancies (27%, 95% CI: 13–48%).
The heterogeneity analysis results showed that
heterogeneity also existed in other factors, such
as cell culture with the addition of IL-2. Table 3 summarized the results of meta-regression analysis.
The result of meta-regression analysis between overall response and different factors showed
regression analysis between complete response and different factors showed that CRR had a

2.6. Meta-Analysis of RR of CAR T Therapy in Patients with Solid and Hematologic Malignancies
overall response after treatment, were eligible for the RR evaluation of CAR T therapy in patients
with solid and hematologic malignancies. The overall pooled RR and 95% CI from the individual
studies were 29% (95% CI: 21–38%) (Figure 4c), with a signiﬁcant heterogeneity (I
The random-effect model was used to calculate them. The subgroup analysis of solid and hematologic
malignancies showed that the RR of patients with hematologic malignancies (29%, 95% CI: 20–40%)
was similar to patients with solid malignancies (27%, 95% CI: 13–48%).
